Course Section: ARTH_V 210-001 - Byzantium: Arts of an Empire

Course Section Definition Public Notes: ARTH 227 revisits modernism in visual art. The course seeks to provide guiding questions for further research by focusing on specific issues in its development: these include definitions of “the modern,” and its effects on the notion of art; the avant-garde and its commitments; the role of women; and the problematic engagement with the Other. The course emphasizes movement and transcultural connections as key dimensions of art. Students will be evaluated based on a combination of individual and group output.

Course Section: ARTH_V 251-001 - Asian Arts: From Chinese Warriors to Bollywood Posters
Course Section Definition Public Notes: This survey highlights connections in the arts, visual and material culture of Asia. Following a roughly chronological order, we will focus on the movement of objects, ideas, people, and artistic practices across Asia. This includes the spread of Buddhist art along the Silk Roads, artistic exchanges in the Mongol Empire, contacts between early modern courts, artistic responses to colonialism and, and Asia in the global contemporary art world. Focusing on these connections allows the examination of selected works across time and space as embedded in changing social, religious, political, and economic frameworks.

Course Section: ARTH_V 262-001 - Indigenous Arts of North America
Course Section Definition Public Notes: ARTH 262: Indigenous Arts of North America is a course on Indigenous artistic practice and visual culture from pre-contact through present day across North America. The course examines arts across generations, and centers notions of land, community, and the exciting resistance and resurgence of Indigenous communities. By looking extensively at contemporary artist’s practices and the historical works and moments that inspired them, participants in this course gain a broad understanding of the history of North America and how this impacts us today. From this, we see how contemporary Indigenous artists honour the work of their ancestors through their practices today.

Course Section: ASIA_V 200-011 - Cultural Foundations of East Asia
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as ‘in-person’ are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

Course Section: ASIX_V 220-011 - Indigeneities in Asia and Asian Diaspora
Course Section Definition Public Notes:
Delivery Mode -This is a synchronous multi-access course. Students are expected to meet on the days and times listed, either in-person or online. All courses labelled ‘multi-access’ offer students the choice of completing the course online, in-person, or using a mix of both. In-person attendance is NOT required, but the option to attend in-person is available. Lectures may be streamed from a classroom and/or uploaded online after class.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.
Please note, students MUST sign up for a tutorial section.
Students MUST sign up for a tutorial.

Course Section: BEST_V 200-101 - Foundations in Bioproducts and the Bioeconomy

Course Section Definition Public Notes: For those who think they have met the pre-reqs but having troubles with registering into BIOC 202, please contact Cyndi Liu (cyndi.liu@ubc.ca).

BIOL 200 uses a staggered seat release during 2nd-year registration and will release a new pool of seats each day of 2nd-year registration.

Students may only register for one required course activity per lecture/lab/discussion or waitlist if there is no space available. Students will be removed from the waitlist if they already have a spot in a section of the course.  For example, students may not register for multiple labs or discussions, including their respective waitlists.  BEING ON THE WAITLIST DOES NOT GUARANTEE YOU A SPACE IN THE LECTURE, LAB, OR DISCUSSION.

Please submit a ticket for any registration issues regarding the course (including requests for tokens for registration).
